instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed â€“ if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT: What is HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT? HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT is a signal from the hall sensor on the RIGHT side of the machine that indicates that the lid has been closed. This is necessary for setting SMC_LID properly so the machine knows whether it is closed or open. When this is low, the machine will think it is closed which may cause it to go to sleep or have no backlight on the screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Arrived with no drop or liquid damage. Board power cycles from 0.01 to 0.06a

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is steady 13V but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> power cycle every few seconds. Not shorted.

Any ideas or sound like bad CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> and check if still pulsing <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Remove <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> and tie together pads 4/6.
Check if get steady voltages for <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Steady 5v at <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> now but drawing 0a

Does this mean <CHIP>U7890</CHIP> should be replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> replaced and <RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> put back.

Steady <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> voltages

PP3V3S5 steady 3.4V

what should be checked next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
This board is having another issue. When the screen is closed, it will not turn back on when opened back up even though board is still running.

<SIGNAL>HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> are low 0.160V.

 <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT_R</SIGNAL> is normal at 3.3V

Replaced <CHIP>U5225</CHIP> and changed flex for J6600 but no change.

Could this be a SMC issue? What should be checked next??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R5257</RESISTOR> and check again.
You may need to change audio flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
With <RESISTOR>R5257</RESISTOR> removed the fan spins for a few seconds then the board turns off. Nothing else happens.

Already changed audio flex as mentioned in last post

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
New issue now even with <RESISTOR>R5257</RESISTOR> put back in place. The board will only power on a few seconds to where the backlight on the screen comes on for 1-2 seconds then the board turns itself off drawing only 0.01a

What could cause this??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Board should start with lid closed; no image/backlight in such case.
Check if you moved something else on the board.

Test the board alone on the desk, only charger connected.
Also try starting in SMC bypass.
